bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Armistead Carter, [19--]

div1.p: Henry Carter informs Laura Carter that he has been working on manuscripts. Henry Carter invites her to visit him.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Armistead Carter, [19--]
div1.opener:
Geddes Va
Sunday A. M
My Dear Daughter:
div1.p:
There is no earthly reason why you sh'd
not do “setting up exercises” now. Indeed I
thought we agreed that you would begin them af-
ter the first 4 or 5 days in bed Tomorrow. or-next
day - will complete your 14 days days rest any
way, & glad am I that you are better. Even if
you did have some indigestion while at rest, yet
you will, on account of the rest, have less n next time-
I felt sure that it would benefit you.

About your coming here I don't know- The
complete change would he no end of a bene-
fit to you - there is little doubt of that - & you
would like the people - much I think - especially
Sally, you would have a chance to ride quite
often & very good horses too, & they - the Misses C.-
occasionally go bathing in Piney River - riding
thereto,- so you w'd have to bring your bathing
suit. On the other hand there is the food prob-
C1
B20
2
problem- Everything is good- but I fear not to you
digestible: vegetables - Potatoes: beets: cabbage:
string beans: some tomatoes & corn rice, stewed
(green) peaches & apples occasionally; Blackberry
Jam: milk: Butter-milk & coffee & good butter.
The bread is corn bread - not batter bread - & biscuits.
& generally underdone i. E white - buiscuits. Have
“light bread” occasionally - & always very good-also
sometimes the buiscuit are good & hard - well
done - quite often since I praised that kind.
Possibly enough you could make out, as I know Sally
would. d meet every special desire you would ex-
press - only one does not like to express them.

She is as nice a girl as one usually seek - nicer indeed
There is also a fair number of fees - not a great
r
number - & I judge that they interfere with sleep in
the day time or even rest, Breakfast is about
8.15 to 8.30 usually. Have had chicken 3 times - 2 fried
& one stewed, no beef or Mutton.
The nights & mornings are cool. Dew lays to about
10. or 10.30 A. M, & after that it is hot in the day
time, sometimes a breeze - there is one now - &
more often not, The house party - M Nannie's
sister & 3 children - have left.

About myself. I have put off writing because
3
I did not know what to say. (1) I have been carefully
over & slowly over my M. S S. for the Oxford
Press - so as to be ready for the Galley Proof - &
the one for Nelson etc, On I have however about
an hours work on the latter yet to do. I will do this
tomorrow A. M. Have not bothered myself
working - except 2 half days - otherwise, I mean
at other times it has been rather an advan-
tage to me. N Worked Have returned - yesterday
- the was address before the H. Officers - & answered
Dr Blanch, Epler & Hoffman - the same day.

It was too hot - to walk much yesterday or Fri-
day. Indeed F. I felt sleepy - all day. Possibly
from reading too late - 12 o' clock - the previous
night, & nearly as late the one before & possibly from
a walk of I judge 2 miles Thursday after-
noon, taken with no rest except to pick black-
berries-. However I was not tired - although
rather wet - when I returned I did not feel
like laying down until bed-time 3 1/2 hours
later. I also am doing setting up exercises
8 sets of them - 25 times each. By the way those
C1
B20
4
that strengthen the abdominal muscles are the
most important for you.

Today - I went out - about 9.3015 - & wa the dew was
less than hitherto - & walked over a mile &
a half & am back, rather moist but not tired.
So I almost think I am well. It It is too hot to
try myself out - but I feel quite sure that I
can do 1 1/2 miles twice a day - with out fatigue
or 2 miles at time. I find too that I am, wal-
king at nearly - not quite - my normal gate. In-
deed I was beginning to do so before I left Balt.

I am thinking then of coming back - say - Aug 1
or July 31: Setting up with the Y. F. (Nelson) ar-
ticle & going on duty. I think I can do so without
any risk at all. That is my present plan - but my
decision is not settled as yet.

If I don't gocome you might consider coming here. I
have told you about how things are. They suit
me well enough - all but the hot weather-
but I am “tougher” than you. If you remember
you did well on coarse food at Chevy Chase. Still
I don't want to risk your what you have gained
5
in your digestion. because I hope the gain will be
-by taking much pains & it may be for some time-
permanent. And that my dear is worth giving
much for: Confound Gertrude Williams any way.

I can't go about to our fishing holes & the play places on
the Summer Hill plantation - they are too far for this
weather - 2 & 3 & 4 miles off. George of course goes on
an artificial leg & crutches. He is not suffering
from diabetes now, only is very aenemic & his
face is puffed - as from Ch. Bright's Disease " He is
I judge going to live sometime- in months or even
a few years-. & die suddenly.

I am going to return your poetry in this as soon
as I have time to reread it.
div1.closer:
H. R. Carter Sally is an extremely nice girl - as
I think are “Miss Jane” & Fanny the-
eldest, Sally has written to accept a
$1200 per an. clerkship at Fort Monroe
H. R. C
